thread.title: Business Breakfast LIVE: Sports Direct profits fall 28% amid House of Fraser takeover

author: Coreena Ford
title: Business Breakfast LIVE: Sports Direct profits fall 28% amid House of Fraser takeover
text:
Coreena Ford Ocado toasts 12% rise in revenues
Ocado has reported a 12% rise in revenue during the final quarter of the year boosted by additional capacity at two new order processing facilities.
The average number of orders per week has jumped by 13.1% to 320,000, but average order size dropped 1% to £104.91.
The firm said its new state of the art facilities at Andover and Erith continue to perform well, with Erith now processing over 30,000 orders per week.
Chief executive Tim Steiner said: “Our unrelenting focus on delivering consistent high levels of service and value to our customers in the U.K. has produced another quarter of satisfying growth.“Although in many respects 2018 has been a transformative year for Ocado, the story has only just begun. We look forward to the coming year and continuing to turn our substantial opportunities into sustainable value for all our stakeholders.” Ocado's Customer Fulfilment Centre in Hatfield 9.00 Coreena Ford Flight academy firm launched at Newcastle Airport by Lord Stevens and young pilot
Former police chief Lord Stevens has teamed up with a North East pilot to launch an in-flight training school .
Based at Newcastle International Airport, the North East Flight Academy has been financed by Lord Stevens, a keen pilot himself, who has joined forces with 25-year-old Ben Harrison, who will run the academy as chief executive.
Lord Stevens is following in the footsteps of his father Steve, also known as CJ, who was the chairman and managing director of BKS Air Transport, the UK’s oldest and largest domestic carrier, which flew charters and freight from 1953 before becoming part of British Airways 20 years later.
Lord Stevens - former chief constable of Northumbria and the Metropolitan Police - has invested a substantial amount in aircraft and facilities to continue the legacy of operating a flying school out of Newcastle Airport.
The North East Flight Academy will offer professional one to one flight training tailored around each individual student, whether they wish to fly for pleasure or become a fully qualified pilot.
The academy’s opening will fill a void left four months ago when training firm PTT Aviation closed its operation at Newcastle and Durham Tees Valley airports, when directors decided to liquidate the business. Left to right: Lord John Stevens of Kirkwhelpington, Northumberland and Ben Harrison chief executive of the North East Flight Academy (Image: The North East Flight Academy) 8.55 Coreena Ford Home buyers and sellers sitting tight as Brexit uncertainty rumbles on
Uncertainty over Brexit is prompting home buyers and sellers to sit tight in increasing numbers, with fewer people interested in moving and properties now typically taking around four months to sell, according to surveyors.
The number of people pondering over a new home fell in November, with a net balance of 21% of surveyors reporting house hunter numbers falling rather than rising, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics) found.
Many comments attributed the drop-off in buyer numbers to Brexit uncertainty as well as a continued limited choice of properties for sale, Rics said.
It now takes 19 weeks on average for a property to sell after initially being listed, the longest duration seen since this aspect of the survey started in February 2017 and “another sign of challenges in the sales market”, Rics said.
House prices are slipping back, despite the limited number of homes for buyers to choose from.
Rics said the regional picture remains varied, with house prices falling most notably in London, South East and East Anglia while house prices in the South West, East Midlands and North East are broadly flat. For Sale signs (Image: PA) 8.50 Coreena Ford Bonmarche shares fall 42% amid "extremely poor" Black Friday trading
Retailer Bonmarche has seen shares almost halve in value after the group warned it could slip to a full-year loss of up to £4m after “extremely poor” Black Friday trading and ongoing subdued shopper demand amid Brexit uncertainty.
Bonmarche said like-for-like sales are expected to fall up to 12% in its third quarter and drop 1% in the final three months.
It now estimates that it will at best break even, but could slip to an underlying pre-tax loss of £4 million for the full year.
Helen Connolly, chief executive of Bonmarche, said:
The current trading conditions are unprecedented in our experience and are significantly worse even than during the recession of 2008/09.
I hope that in the fullness of time our cut to the forecast may prove to have been overdone, but in the current market this seems the appropriate stance to adopt. I believe that Bonmarche is well prepared to weather the storm, and that we can look forward to some recovery in FY20.
Shares in Bonmarche fell 42% in morning trading, having opened as much as 50% lower. A Bonmarche store Coreena Ford Watch Newcastle University's Richardson Road flats get demolished and re-built - in 60 seconds
A £75m student accommodation scheme at Newcastle University has welcomed its first student residents after the biggest project of its kind in the UK.
The former Richardson Road student housing was razed to the ground two years ago to make way for the new Park View Student Village at the university’s bigggest accommodation site.
Now the site h as been officially opened by Newcastle University vice-chancellor Professor Chris Day in a ceremony attended by university staff , teams from the principal contractor, Galliford Try plc, and members of the public. 8.40 Coreena Ford Revolut secures European banking licence ahead of Brexit
Fintech start-up Revolut has secured a European banking licence as it steps up preparations for a hard Brexit.
The company, which launched three years ago allowing customers to transfer money abroad with the real exchange rate, sought the licence partly to “hedge against any issues regarding Brexit”, according a source.
The source added that Revolut intends to apply for a UK banking licence but has not yet officially done so, and will provide further information in the new year.
Revolut secured the licence from the Bank of Lithuania and it was approved by the European Central Bank.
Uncertainty surrounding the UK’s departure from the European Union at the end of March has been raised after Conservative MPs triggered a vote of no confidence in Prime Minister Theresa May.
After Brexit, financial services companies in the UK will lose passporting rights to trade with firms across European Union’s single market. The company said it will take three to six months for Revolut to begin passporting its banking licence across Europe, focusing initially on the UK, France and Poland. 8.35 Coreena Ford Tui overcomes heatwave hit
Holiday giant Tui has shrugged off a summer heatwave hit to its tour operator and airlines division to report a 10.9% rise in annual earnings, but it warned “challenging” trading will continue.
The group said the prolonged hot weather across the UK and Europe, together with the impact of air traffic control strike action and the Brexit-hit pound combined to send earnings in the tour operator and airlines business down 14.6% to 449.8 million euros (£405.1m).
But an impressive performance in its hotels and resorts arm and cruises business offset the impact, helping underlying earnings rise to 1.22 billion euros (£1.1bn), with currency effects stripped out, for the year to September 30.
Tui admitted it was a “challenging” year for the tour operator and airlines division and said this will continue into 2019.
Winter bookings for 2018-19 are 1% lower, while prices are down 2%.
It said:
The weakness of pound sterling resulting from the Brexit vote, prolonged air traffic disruption caused by French air traffic controller strikes and a prolonged heatwave in northern and central Europe impacted the entire sector and were also reflected in the operating result delivered by markets and airlines, which fell short of the previous year’s levels.
Rivals have also been knocked hard by the heatwave and strike action, with Thomas Cook issuing a series of recent profit warnings as the hot weather took its toll. But Tui said it expects earnings to grow at least 10% again in 2019 as the rest of the business should offset the tough trading in the tour operator and airlines arm. A TUI plane is di-iced at Newcastle International Airport (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 8.30 KEY EVENT Sports Direct profits fall 28% amid House of Fraser takeover
Sports Direct boss Mike Ashley has said the company faces “significant challenges” turning House of Fraser around, as profits took a hit from the department store acquisition.
The group’s underlying pre-tax profits dropped 26.8% to £64.4m in the 26 weeks to October 28, the period in which it acquired House of Fraser out of administration.
However grew 4.5% to £1.79bn, reflecting growth Ashley reiterated his pledge to make House of Fraser the Harrods of the High Street, but said it would be a challenging process.
“I This means we have significant challenges ahead in turning House of Fraser around,” he said.

It has long been speculated that Mr Ashley would stage a takeover of Debenhams, in which Sports Direct has a 29.7% stake.
